PM

Traditional analysis of China's growth slowdown impact on a certain geographical
area or sector tends to focus only the first order impact on that particular region or
asset. In a sense this is partial equilibrium analysis, which understates the true
impact on economic and financial variables globally as it misses the indirect
impacts of a slowdown elsewhere in the globe. In this note we try to
simultaneously determine the reaction to an extremely unlikely China "worst case"
shock on China-hit economies in different regions, and on different asset markets.
Each number is determined not just by the (negative) stimulus from China, but also
by the contemporaneous hit to numbers elsewhere. We also try to account for
impacts beyond just the first round; and assess second round iterations on
economies from any subsequent tightening of monetary and financial conditions in
local or global asset markets.

PM

The primary conduit of transmission of weaker Chinese FAI growth to global assets
is lower commodity prices. This is where we begin our asset market analysis. We
then look further at how this impacts credit spreads, and how credit spreads and
weaker growth, in turn, impact equity markets, rates and FX markets.
We would note that analysis that bases the hit to the global economy purely on
China's contribution to global growth in recent years will overestimate the impact
of a weaker China. This is because: (a) developed economies are less open than
EM economies, so will suffer less from weaker external demand, and (b) the world
is not Renminbi financed, which should mean that rising credit or banking system
risk in China will unlikely lead to a credit crunch globally.
In the highly unlikely (in our view) China worst case scenario, a sharper slowdown
and prolonged destocking process in China's property and industrial sector leads
to an even faster fixed investment decline and GDP growth sliding to 4%. Figure 1
summarizes elements of such a Chinese worst case scenario:

PM

Here's fig 1

In Figure 2 we summarize the overall impact across the most relevant economies
and asset classes from a China worst case scenario.

summarizes the range of stock specific impact that our equity sector analysts
selected and highlighted from their coverage universe. The complete list of specific
names and sector commentaries are shown in the last section of this document.

Data from the American Petroleum Institute (API) yesterday showed crude
stocks fell last week by 5.6 million barrels, while stocks at the

Energy Information Administration (EIA) will publish its closely
watched weekly petroleum data at 1630 CET. US inventories are
expected to have risen by 439,000 barrels last week, according to a
Reuters poll. A senior Iranian oil official said the country could
moderate oil output and exports once Western sanctions are lifted
to avoid putting prices under further pressure, according to a
Reuters interview.

BE

First thoughts and the basic numbers: The move could be seen as
opportunistic given the basic numbers on Home Retail (HOME.LN, 134p, Buy).
Home Retail's market cap (at 134p per share) is c.£1.1bn, it has net cash of
c.£250m, Argos Store card debtors of c.£650m and we forecast EBITDA of
£233m for the year to February 2016.
While Sainsbury's is currently out-executing its big box grocery retailers,
grocery industry growth prospects are poor and the ongoing shift to
convenience and online will make store space less and less productive,
creating opportunities to fill that space.

BE

From a wider strategic perspective, the combined group has the potential to
properly rival the increasingly imminent prospect of Amazon's combined food
and non-food offer with its own combined food and non-food proposition. This
would be tied to a very strong collection and delivery network and capability.

BE

Positives: There is considerable flexibility to reduce the rental bill (c.£150m at
Argos, c.£150m at Homebase), with average lease expiries at Argos of

BE

Negatives: Execution could be tricky. We have concerns about the strength of
the Argos systems and moves to merge product files, distribution networks,
EPOS systems and delivery networks could take significant time and
investment.
The Argos brand is not as strong as that of Sainsbury's and sits, in our view,
downmarket of Sainsbury's. However, we see the potential for a "halo" benefit
to Sainsbury's stores of Argos footfall.

BE

And RBC, historically the most bullish on HOME.

11:31 am
BE

Given Home Retail’s low valuation and potential for a value-enhancing “shrink-to-grow” strategy, we are not surprised to see further bid speculation although were not expecting to see interest from a trade buyer such as Sainsbury’s. Having said that, we do think there is some strategic rationale behind a potential acquisition. Sainsbury’s already has a working relationship with Home Retail through its trial of 10 Argos inserts in Sainsbury’s stores and also from its previous ownership of Homebase which it founded in 1979. In the event of an acquisition, there would likely be some small purchasing synergy benefits but more
importantly we think there would be huge potential for store rationalisation by shutting existing Argos stores and potentially converting some to food space subject to planning permission. Sainsbury’s would also benefit from the take-up of excess space within its stores and had previously identified c1.5m sq ft of food retail space that it intended to convert to non-food space. The rollout of small, high density Argos pick-up points would allow Sainsbury’s to offer a full food and non-food offer across a more optimised store estate. There are nearly 600 Sainsbury’s stores in the UK of which 434 are over 20k sq ft, thus could be large enough to insert an Argos concession, in our view.

On the other hand, execution risk would undoubtedly be high and we also think there might be some brand issues given the lower socio-demographic profile of Argos customers. Sainsbury’s also cited Argos’ delivery network as an advantage of a tie-up, but this has not been without its challenges this year owing to a build-up of operating cost and stock availability issues. In our October report (Home Retail Group - Examining the strategic options) we highlighted the potential value in Home Retail with the right strategy and execution. The company is cash generative, runs a large loan book and has a flexible lease portfolio (over half of Argos’ leases are due for renewal over the next 5 years). We also highlighted potential bid activity as one of our year ahead themes and cited Home Retail as a reasonable bid target (Outlook 2016: European General Retail - Staying online in 2016). We value Home Retail at 125p in our base case sum-of-the-parts but our bull case is 230p which supports the idea that Sainsbury’s or another buyer may re-approach Home Retail with a higher bid. Even after the 40%+ move in the share price yesterday, we think Home Retail's valuation remains inexpensive at 5.2x CY16E EV/EBITDAR and CY16E PE of 12x vs the sector averages of 8.8x and 14.8x respectively.

As such, and in advance of Home Retail’s Q3 IMS on 14th January, we retain our Outperform rating. We think expectations for Q3 are fairly low and see upside risk to Argos LFLs given its focus on driving volume over peak through new delivery services and marketing. However a stronger electricals performance over Black Friday provides some downside risk to Argos’ gross margin in our view owing to a negative mix impact.

In terms of readacross for the rest of the sector, we think that Sainsbury’s interest in Home Retail will give some strategic support to the mid-cap space in what is currently a tough trading environment. We see potential for renewed bouts of strategic and takeover speculation, as investors recognise the brand value, asset values and competitive strengths of retailers, their fairly simple, understandable business models and their strong cashflow characteristics, which support a fairly high degree of leverage in the sector. In particular, we point to the wave of department store consolidation activity over the last five years and in 2015, which we think may continue into 2016. Sainsbury’s bid for Home Retail could also be a positive for Kingfisher given Homebase could be downsized more aggressively under new ownership.

BE

And Freddie George at Cantor.

BE

Our View: There is no doubt in our view that Home Retail is ‘in play’ and there are likely to be other predators for the group. . J Sainsbury (SBRY LN – HOLD (from BUY) – TP 270p (from 312p), we suspect, would plan to dispose of Homebase and look to restructure the Argos estate, which had an average length of lease of under five years, with a focus on hub stores and concessions. Although the forthcoming trading statement may be disappointing we believe there is significant intrinsic value in the business. The stock is still rated at just over 3x FY2016 EV/EBITDA, while the company has a break-up value of over 260p per share on our estimates. We retain our BUY recommendation and our TP of 195p.
· Timing of offer is slightly baffling – Home Retail is due to put out a trading update on January 14th – J Sainsbury confirms that it made a possible offer for Home Retail in November, which has been rejected, in the form of equity and cash. The announcement was released after 12:00am reportedly because the Home Retail share price had risen by more than 10%. Argos will, we believe, advance Sainsbury’s multi-channel effort, strengthen its non-food offer and improve its financial services proposition. There should also be significant scope for synergies.
· Argos will have expertise in logistics and the fast growing ‘click and collect’ – In our September note – “Reached rock bottom”, we commented on the following – ‘Argos has become one of the few retailers, which will have full control of its infrastructure from order to despatch to customer and every process in between. It will continue to develop its systems, including its ‘hub to home’ offering in FY2016, broaden its ranges, optimise its trading estate and most importantly, develop its third party business, which has encouragingly started with the eBay contract (EBAY US – HOLD – TP US$ 27). It should also benefit from a further easing in the competitive trading environment with competitors likely to have to start charging customers for ‘check and reserve’.
· Break-up value is over 260p per share – Home Retail has one of the strongest balance sheets in the General Retail sector with cash forecast at £292m at February 2016, mail order debtors of £580m and relatively high levels of provisioning. It also has a break-up value on our estimates of over 260p per share, including 106p attributable to the cash balance and the debtors file and assuming that Homebase has a zero value. On our top of the range FY2016 pre-tax profit forecast of £118m, the stock is rated at 12.3x FY2016 earnings and 3.1x EV/EBITDA with a dividend yield of c.3%.

11:32 am

If you want the bit on Royal Mail specifically, here it is.

BE

We see three key issues for 2016. The current wage deal expires in March and we expect a
new deal to be negotiated during the first quarter of the year. Management is moving
towards the closure of the defined benefit pension scheme, which will become unaffordable
once the current contribution deal with the trustees expires in 2018; we would expect this
to be resolved in the second half of the year and require some asset injection to close. The
regulatory review, which is focusing on the access regime, has no fixed timetable within
2016, but the regulator expects next steps to be announced in Q1.

In terms of the outlook, 2015 guidance was updated with the interim results; costs are now
expected to go down by 1-2% rather than 0-1%, which is a consequence of the
announcement that Royal Mail has scoped and initiated a £500m cost avoidance
programme to run to the end of 2017-18. This is expected to be delivered in a relatively
linear fashion across that period, implying that total costs in UKPIL are held flat in nominal
terms during that time, allowing any revenue growth to fall to the bottom line.
Valuation
Recognising that Royal Mail is in a period of transformation and should deliver higher
growth than its postal peers over the next 3-5 years, we take the dividend for FY 2017 of
23p and apply a 4% yield, a premium to the peer group, where we use 5%, to arrive at our
target price.

BE

So, cheap assuming it sacks a load of posties.

11:40 am
BE

(It said that a few days ago, but I forgot to mention at the time so here it is.)

BE

■ Three key factors fuel our doubts: (i) RMG core focus needs to be on self-help: RMG remains a multi-year restructuring story with top line challenges in mail and parcel, and we think mgt will be more likely to retain cash for restructuring than spending on significant M&A, which would also risk distracting attention from the task at hand, (ii) limited synergy prospects: synergy prospects would appear limited given limited mail or parcel network overlap (beyond the c20% of access mail provided to RMG by PostNL's Whistl!) and cost bases dominated by labour, (iii) PostNL outlook difficult to forecast: PostNL's core mail volume declines (5-9% annually expected for 2015-2020, versus double digits over recent history) and need to discount to preserve bulk share present significant risks that returns from any potential combination would be challenging to predict, rendering net synergy estimates unreliable. Further, PostNL's recent experience with the Dutch regulator (November's strategy update confirmed its expectation of a €30m-€50m hit from Significant Market Power measures), potentially increased labour difficulties under foreign ownership and the need to invest to at-best protect parcel margins provide further question marks.

BE

■ Underperform with a TP of 400p: We value Royal Mail at 400p per share, based on a blend of multiples, DCF and SOTP metrics. It currently trades on a 2016E EV/EBITDA multiple of 5.7x and a FCF yield of 5%.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc (VRX.TO) (VRX.N) will appoint an interim chief executive officer to replace Michael Pearson who is hospitalized, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters, news that sent shares down 7 percent on Tuesday. The source did not clarify whether the CEO would be temporary or would permanently replace Pearson, 56, who is recovering from a severe case of pneumonia.

Pearson's hospitalization, disclosed on Dec. 25, is the latest challenge for the Canadian drugmaker whose shares have fallen nearly 60 percent since late August in the face of questions from Congress, investors and customers about how it prices and sells drugs.

All companies have now announced receipt of payments for respectively Tawke, Taq
Taq, and Shaikan fields totalling $75m. This is the 4th payment since the start of a
more predictable timetable for revenue payments, and at the same gross level of $75m
combined. We assume this payment refers to December deliveries. Previously the KRG
had indicated that the payment schedule would be in the range of $75-100m, and so
far it has consistently been at the lower figure, with the plan to increase the level early in
'16. In our view although of course continued predictable payments are important, the next significant catalyst for these companies would be an increase to at least the $100m
level, which we believe would demonstrate the KRG commitment and to improving
overall conditions in KRI.

DNO – DNO and Gulf Keystone today reported that KRG have paid
USD 30m to the Tawke partners and USD 15m to the Shaikan
partners for December exports (the fourth export payment since
start-up in September). This follows yesterday’s announcement
from Genel of December payment for Taq Taq of USD 30m, and the
amounts are equal to those in previous months (USD 75m in total
per month. At the current oil price levels KRG’s revenues are
estimated at around USD 500-600m, and with around USD 800m of
monthly expenses, KRG is running with a deficit. The fact that KRG is
still continuing with the export payments is an indication of the high

BE

11:53 am
BE

With rising probability of an EM credit cycle likely to be priced into
bank valuations, we expect HSBC to underperform relative to European banks
(SX7P). We see valuation downside due to i) potential for rising NPL inflows
in EM; ii) revenue pressure persisting despite US rates; and iii) little or no
growth in DPS given EPS downside risk and rising stated payout. We note
that the market is pricing an EM NPL cycle into StanChart’s valuation which
trades at a 40% discount to HSBC (0.6x P/TNAV vs 1.0x on FY15E), has
improved capital (CET1 of 13.0% at STAN vs 12.3% pro-forma HSBC) and
has already cut DPS to preserve capital. For dividend yield, we prefer Lloyds,
which remains our top UK bank pick.

BE

 Loan impairment risks have increased: We expect a modest increase in
impairment with risks to the downside in 2016/17, primarily driven by Asia
which is currently running at 13bps LLP (3Q15). We note that our current
forecast 2017 group impairment of 39bps remains well below the long-term
average (104bps over 20y). Assuming 50bps/75bps would reduce 2017E
RoTE from 10.5% to 9.9%8.7%.
 Pre-provision profits growth limited: We believe management's cost
focus is a positive with costs expected to remain flat over 2014-17E on an
FX adjusted basis. However, we expect pressure on revenue to continue
with the group restructuring $220bn RWAs over this period (ex Brazil &
Turkey disposals) and a challenging outlook for redeployment into higher
return business (c$150bn). We forecast underlying revenues (ex disposals)
to be flat in 2016 and see downside risk to our forecasts.
 A flat DPS requires payout to rise above 40-60% target: We forecast
DPS to remain flat at 50c in 2015 and 2016 with the stated DPS payout ratio
rising to 78% in 2016, which is well beyond the group’s 40-60% target
range. We don’t expect a DPS cut, but do not assume neutralization of the
group‘s scrip dividend (c30%).
 JPM estimates are below consensus: Relative to company consensus, we
are 2% 3% below on Revs and 4%/ 6% below on DPS in 16E/17E.

BE

While these reports add a level of concern
to March iPhones, we believe investors are appropriately pricing in the potential for
a disappointing March. We note that the best read on overall iPhones is Apple's
December guide and the company has not missed a guide since changing its guidance
methods almost three full years ago. We believe the December guide implies slight
growth of iPhone y/y including CEO Tim Cook's specific mention that iPhones would
grow y/y. Overall, this data point, albeit old, lends us confidence that March may not
be as bad as expected assuming that if iPhone demand is up slightly in December and
the overall smartphone market is stable with a large upgrade base of existing iPhone
users, we would expect narrower change in the December and March growth rates.

11:59 am
BE

An important factor that is missed in the
attention to concerning March data points is that the optimism for iPhone growth
improves as comps get easier. While this may seem a long way away, investors are
largely waiting for the the Dec-15 earnings report/Mar-16 guide as a buying window
for AAPL shares ahead of the 2H16 growth improvements. We believe the hyperconcern
around the bigger picture that the iPhone franchise is healthy and will benefit
over the next several years from the move to annual upgrade programs. We have
previously said that this could add a 5-7% tailwind to iPhone units over the next
several years.

12:01 pm
BE

Recent media reports suggest Apple is cutting iPhone 6S/6S+ build
plans for the March quarter and many have pointed to lower 6S/6S+ demand
at carriers versus the 6/6+. We believe the latter should not be surprising as
history has shown that S-cycles typically have lower units per carrier than non-S
cycles. We also believe unit strength could come from lower end models and note
that in the 5S cycle, Apple saw strength from the 4S due to strategic actions in
various markets. We expect the addback of $5-$10 per device, the Ericsson IP
deal, and potential other balance sheet actions could result in stronger gross
margins (shifting the story for the time being to a margin story). Nonetheless, we
are lowering our March quarter estimates and our valuation range ($120-$130
from $125-$135) to err on the side of conservatism. Our new FQ2 EPS of $2.33 is
below the Street’s $2.37, which creates some sentiment risk (though we believe
the recent pullback reflects this). Despite the near-term issues, we reiterate our
Outperform rating as we believe iPhone units have not peaked and will grow in
the 7 cycle as non-S cycles typically have higher units per carrier vs S-cycles (and
assuming flat carriers). We lower our FY2016E EPS to $9.60 from $9.66. We
raise our December 2016E EPS to $3.52 from $3.33 and FY2017E to $10 from
$9.76. While AAPL shares may require a little patience during this transition, we
believe the risk/reward is favorable at 8.1x our FY2016 FCF estimate (10.7x EPS)
and a FCF yield of 12.3%.

BE
